Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Bat Flight Motion Capture via Multi-View Imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bats are the most dynamic and agile fliers in the animal kingdom, and, as such, they are excellent candidates for the inspiration of new flapping wing micro-air vehicle technology. The impressive flight mechanics of these animals is due to the complex nature of their wing structure. However, the simplicity of their muscle-tendon system suggests that the underlying mechanics of the wing motion is not as complex as it appears. The goal of this research is to determine how the bats control their wings to enable the development of flapping-wing micro-air vehicles which mimic the flight mechanics of the bat.The researcher will perform motion capture studies of bats in flight to determine wing and body motion during different flight maneuvers. This research will be conducted at Shandong University in Jinan, China under the supervision of an expert in the field, Dr. Rolf Mueller, who has studied bats for over 20 years. Over 100 species of bats have been documented in China which makes it an attractive location for observing cross specie trends in bat flight.

To study these animals, a multi-camera motion capture array will be used to record high speed video of the bats in as many flight regimes as possible. Many viewing angles are required for this research because the highly articulated nature of the wing results in self-occlusion of important aspects of wing motion. The researchers are interested in capturing as many flight regimes as possible to determine how the bat controls different modes of flight. While similar research has been previously conducted, our experiments are novel for three reasons. First, limited motion capture data is available for Great Himalayan Round Nose Leaf bat, and to analyze cross-species trends in flight, more species data is needed. Second, we use many inexpensive cameras rather than few expensive cameras and have constructed a motion capture system for a fraction of the cost of commercially available systems. Finally, the researchers aim to create a repository of bat flight motion capture data that any researcher can use for extensions of this work including computational fluid dynamics simulations, motion estimation algorithm development, and micro-air vehicle design. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The researcher performed motion capture studies of bats in flight to determine wing and body motion during straight and level flight. This research was conducted at Shandong University in Jinan, China under the supervision of Dr. Rolf Mueller who has studied bats for over 20 years. The goal of this research is to determine how the bats move their wings.  This research will enable the development of flapping-wing micro-air vehicles which mimic the flight mechanics of the bat.

To study these animals, a multi-camera motion capture array was developed to record high speed video of the bats in flight.  Many viewing angles are required for this research because the highly articulated nature of the wing results in self-occlusion of important aspects of wing motion.  While similar research has been previously conducted, our experiments were novel for two reasons.  First, limited motion capture data is available for Great Himalayan Round Nose Leaf bat.  To analyze cross-species trends in flight, more species data is needed.  Second, we used many inexpensive cameras rather than few expensive cameras and have constructed a motion capture system for a fraction of the cost of commercially available systems. Using many cameras to observe bat flight prevents markers from becoming occluded due to the complex motion of the bat wing.  Our experiments produced several runs of straight flight in which no point markers attached to the wing were completely occluded (i.e. visible in fewer than 2 cameras at any time step).  Therefore, our data does not require interpolation to fill in missing data.  

The system created for this project has been under development for two years, one summer of which was funded by this grant.  After further collaborations with Shandong University and Virginia Tech, the researchers are now able to synchronize all 40 cameras in the motion capture array.  This advancement will be critical for insuring the fidelity and accuracy of future data collected, both at SDU and VT.  Eventually, an open-source data repository of bat flight motion capture experiments will be made available to anyone interested in using the data for further studies.
